bastar-dussehra.name: Bastar Dussehra
bastar-dussehra.tagline: The world's longest Dussehra celebrated without Rama or Ravana
bastar-dussehra.description:
**Bastar Dussehra** is one of the most unique and ancient festivals of India, celebrated in the Bastar region of Chhattisgarh.

Unlike classical Dussehra, this festival does **not** commemorate the victory of Rama over Ravana. Instead, it is entirely dedicated to **Goddess Danteshwari**, the presiding deity of Bastar.

The festival spans nearly **75 days**, making it the longest Dussehra celebration in the world.

• Organized and conducted by tribal communities
• Deeply rooted in tribal rituals and beliefs
• Symbolizes unity between the king, tribes, and the goddess
bastar-dussehra.meaning:
The festival represents devotion to Goddess Danteshwari and reflects the traditional governance system where tribal consent and participation are central.

It symbolizes the spiritual bond between nature, tribal society, and divine power.

traditions.title: Pat Jatra
traditions.description: The ceremonial permission ritual that marks the beginning of Bastar Dussehra, seeking divine consent to start the festival.

traditions.title: Kachan Gadi
traditions.description: Construction of a symbolic chariot using traditional methods without nails, representing tribal craftsmanship.

traditions.title: Rath Yatra
traditions.description: A massive wooden chariot is pulled by thousands of devotees, symbolizing collective devotion and unity.

traditions.title: Muria Darbar
traditions.description: A traditional assembly where tribal leaders present grievances and issues, continuing the age-old system of public dialogue.

rajim-kumbh-kalp.name: Rajim Kumbh Kalp
rajim-kumbh-kalp.tagline: The spiritual confluence of faith, rivers, and tradition
rajim-kumbh-kalp.description:
**Rajim Kumbh Kalp** is a major spiritual and cultural festival held at the sacred Triveni Sangam in Chhattisgarh, where the **Mahanadi, Pairi, and Sondur rivers** meet.

Often referred to as the *Prayagraj of Chhattisgarh*, the festival attracts saints, pilgrims, and devotees from across the state.

• Sacred river bathing rituals
• Spiritual discourses and satsangs
• Blend of tribal and classical traditions
rajim-kumbh-kalp.meaning:
The festival symbolizes spiritual purification, devotion, and harmony between nature and faith.

It also represents Chhattisgarh’s identity as a land of ancient river-based culture.

traditions.title: Triveni Snan
traditions.description: Devotees take a holy dip at the river confluence believing it cleanses sins and grants spiritual merit.

traditions.title: Sant Samagam
traditions.description: Saints and spiritual leaders conduct discourses, prayers, and philosophical discussions.

hareli.name: Hareli
hareli.tagline: A festival celebrating farming, cattle, and greenery
hareli.description:
**Hareli** is one of the most important agricultural festivals of Chhattisgarh, marking the beginning of the monsoon and the farming season.

The festival reflects the deep bond between farmers, cattle, and nature.

• Worship of farming tools
• Care and decoration of cattle
• Symbol of prosperity and greenery
hareli.meaning:
Hareli signifies gratitude towards nature and animals that sustain agricultural life.

It emphasizes harmony between humans, livestock, and the environment.

traditions.title: Tool Worship
traditions.description: Agricultural tools are cleaned and worshipped to pray for a successful farming season.

traditions.title: Cattle Decoration
traditions.description: Cows and bullocks are bathed, decorated, and honored as symbols of wealth and strength.

teeja.name: Teeja (Teej)
teeja.tagline: A festival of devotion, fasting, and marital faith
teeja.description:
**Teeja**, also known as **Teej**, is a traditional festival primarily observed by married women.

The festival is dedicated to devotion, marital well-being, and feminine strength.

• Observed through fasting
• Traditional songs and swings
• Strong social and emotional significance
teeja.meaning:
Teeja represents dedication, patience, and faith in marital life.

It strengthens social bonds and preserves age-old traditions centered around womanhood.

traditions.title: Nirjala Vrat
traditions.description: Women observe a strict fast without food or water, praying for their husband’s long life.

traditions.title: Folk Singing
traditions.description: Women sing traditional songs expressing emotions, devotion, and cultural stories.

pola.name: Pola
pola.tagline: Honoring the strength of bulls and farming life
pola.description:
**Pola** is an agricultural festival dedicated to bulls, which are essential to traditional farming practices.

The festival reflects respect for animals that support rural livelihoods.

• Bulls are decorated and worshipped
• Farming communities gather and celebrate
• Strong rural identity
pola.meaning:
Pola symbolizes gratitude towards bulls for their role in agriculture.

It reinforces respect for labor, animals, and rural traditions.

traditions.title: Bull Worship
traditions.description: Bulls are washed, decorated, and honored through rituals and prayers.

traditions.title: Village Processions
traditions.description: Decorated bulls are paraded through villages accompanied by music and celebration.

navakhani.name: Navakhani
navakhani.tagline: Celebrating the first harvest of the season
navakhani.location: Tribal regions of Bastar and surrounding districts
navakhani.description:
**Navakhani** is a traditional tribal harvest festival celebrated to mark the consumption of the new rice crop.

Before eating the freshly harvested grain, rituals are performed to offer the first portion to local deities and ancestors.

• Celebration of new rice harvest
• Ritual offering before first consumption
• Community-based thanksgiving ceremony
navakhani.meaning:
Navakhani symbolizes gratitude toward nature and ancestral spirits for a successful harvest.

It reinforces the tribal belief that food must first be offered to divine forces before human consumption.

traditions.title: New Rice Offering
traditions.description: Freshly harvested rice is cooked and offered to village deities before families partake in the meal.

traditions.title: Community Feast
traditions.description: Villagers gather to share meals and celebrate the prosperity of the season.

goncha-festival.name: Goncha Festival
goncha-festival.tagline: A unique chariot festival with symbolic fruit cannons
goncha-festival.description:
**Goncha Festival** is a distinctive tribal celebration held in Bastar during the monsoon season.

The festival features a grand chariot procession and the playful use of traditional wooden guns that fire small fruits known as *goncha*.

• Rath Yatra of local deities
• Symbolic fruit shooting tradition
• Blend of devotion and festivity
goncha-festival.meaning:
Goncha represents devotion combined with celebration and tribal identity.

It reflects how classical traditions adapt uniquely within Bastar’s cultural landscape.

traditions.title: Rath Procession
traditions.description: The deity is carried in a decorated chariot through the town accompanied by music and chants.

traditions.title: Goncha Firing
traditions.description: Participants use wooden cannons to shoot small fruits in a symbolic and playful ritual.

madai-festival.name: Madai Festival
madai-festival.tagline: A traveling tribal festival of devotion and trade
madai-festival.description:
**Madai Festival** is not confined to a single location; it is a moving tribal celebration that travels from village to village.

It combines religious rituals, local markets, and vibrant cultural performances.

• Seasonal traveling celebration
• Worship of village deities
• Traditional fairs and trade gatherings
madai-festival.meaning:
Madai strengthens inter-village relationships and preserves tribal governance traditions.

It also acts as a social and economic gathering where communities exchange goods and culture.

traditions.title: Deity Procession
traditions.description: Village deities are carried ceremonially to designated grounds for worship.

traditions.title: Traditional Fair
traditions.description: Local markets are set up where people trade forest produce, crafts, and livestock.

chherchhera.name: Chherchhera
chherchhera.tagline: A harvest-sharing festival of generosity and community
chherchhera.description:
**Chherchhera** is a traditional harvest festival celebrated on the full moon of the Paush month.

The festival revolves around sharing newly harvested rice and grains within the community.

Children and villagers go door-to-door singing traditional lines and asking for grains, symbolizing equality and collective prosperity.

• Celebration after harvest season
• Community grain sharing ritual
• Strong rural identity
chherchhera.meaning:
Chherchhera reinforces the idea that prosperity must be shared.

It strengthens social bonds and reflects the agrarian foundation of Chhattisgarh’s culture.

traditions.title: Door-to-Door Grain Collection
traditions.description: Children visit households singing traditional chants and collect rice or grains as symbolic offerings.

traditions.title: Community Distribution
traditions.description: Collected grains are shared or used for community meals, promoting unity and equality.

raut-nacha.name: Raut Nacha
raut-nacha.tagline: The warrior dance festival of the Yadav community
raut-nacha.description:
**Raut Nacha** is a vibrant festival celebrated primarily by the Yadav (Raut) community after Diwali.

It commemorates the martial spirit and devotion of Lord Krishna while showcasing energetic group dance performances.

Performers wear traditional attire and carry sticks or swords, moving rhythmically to drums and folk music.

• Community-based warrior dance
• Celebration after Diwali
• Strong link to Krishna devotion
raut-nacha.meaning:
Raut Nacha symbolizes bravery, devotion, and community pride.

It preserves oral traditions, music, and dance heritage passed through generations.

traditions.title: Warrior Dance Processions
traditions.description: Groups perform synchronized dances in village streets using sticks or traditional weapons.

traditions.title: Krishna Devotional Songs
traditions.description: Folk songs narrating stories of Lord Krishna are sung during performances.

traditions.title: Community Visits
traditions.description: Dance troupes visit different villages, strengthening inter-community ties.

goura-gouri.name: Goura-Gouri Festival
goura-gouri.tagline: A sacred celebration of divine marital harmony
goura-gouri.location: Rural and tribal regions of Chhattisgarh
goura-gouri.description:
**Goura-Gouri Festival** is a traditional celebration honoring the divine couple, Lord Shiva (Goura) and Goddess Parvati (Gouri).

Clay idols of the deities are crafted and worshipped with songs and rituals.

The festival highlights marital harmony, fertility, and family prosperity.

• Idol crafting and worship
• Community singing and rituals
• Strong rural participation
goura-gouri.meaning:
The festival emphasizes marital unity, devotion, and domestic harmony.

It reflects deep-rooted traditions centered around family and agricultural life.

traditions.title: Clay Idol Installation
traditions.description: Handcrafted clay idols of Goura and Gouri are installed and worshipped in homes or community spaces.

traditions.title: Folk Ritual Singing
traditions.description: Women and elders sing traditional songs narrating divine love and blessings.

karma-festival.name: Karma Festival
karma-festival.tagline: A tribal celebration of nature, youth, and destiny
karma-festival.location: Northern and tribal regions of Chhattisgarh
karma-festival.description:
**Karma Festival** is an important tribal celebration dedicated to the worship of the **Karam tree**, symbolizing fate and prosperity.

Celebrated mainly by tribal communities, the festival is centered around youth participation, music, and all-night dance rituals.

• Worship of the sacred Karam tree branch
• Community dance and drum performances
• Celebration of fertility and prosperity
karma-festival.meaning:
Karma represents the belief that human destiny is linked to nature.

The festival reinforces unity among youth and strengthens tribal identity through collective celebration.

traditions.title: Karam Tree Worship
traditions.description: A branch of the Karam tree is planted in the village ground and worshipped with offerings.

traditions.title: Karma Dance
traditions.description: Men and women perform rhythmic group dances throughout the night accompanied by drums.

sarhul.name: Sarhul
sarhul.tagline: Welcoming spring through sacred forest worship
sarhul.description:
**Sarhul** is a spring festival celebrated by tribal communities to honor the **Sal tree** and the spirit of the forest.

It marks the beginning of the new year in many tribal calendars and celebrates the blooming of nature.

• Worship of Sal tree flowers
• Ritual offerings to village spirits
• Celebration of ecological harmony
sarhul.meaning:
Sarhul symbolizes respect for forests and the earth.

It reflects the tribal worldview that humans are protectors—not owners—of nature.

traditions.title: Sal Flower Offering
traditions.description: Priests offer newly bloomed Sal flowers to village deities seeking protection and prosperity.

traditions.title: Community Feast
traditions.description: Villagers gather for shared meals and traditional dance celebrations.

bhojali.name: Bhojali Festival
bhojali.tagline: A women-led monsoon ritual of devotion and greenery
bhojali.description:
**Bhojali Festival** is primarily celebrated by young girls and women during the monsoon season.

Seeds are sown in small baskets and nurtured for several days, symbolizing growth, fertility, and devotion.

• Ritual sowing of seeds
• Devotional songs by women
• Immersion ceremony in water bodies
bhojali.meaning:
Bhojali represents nurturing energy and agricultural fertility.

It highlights the role of women as preservers of cultural and ecological traditions.

traditions.title: Seed Sowing Ritual
traditions.description: Grains are planted in baskets and cared for daily as a sacred responsibility.

traditions.title: Bhojali Visarjan
traditions.description: The grown green shoots are immersed in rivers or ponds accompanied by songs.
